facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 165 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Patna High Court judgment and order dated 4th August 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 4th August, 1955, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 699 of 1953 with Criminal Revision No. 205

facts.text: Patna High Court case arose from Criminal Appeal No. 699 of 1953 with Criminal Revision No. 205 of 1954.

facts.text: Trial conducted by Assistant Sessions Judge, Second Court Chapra in Trial No. 70 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 12th December, 1953, of the Court of the Assistant Sessions Judge, Second Court Chapra in Trial No. 70 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellants along with others tried before Assistant Sessions Judge of Chapra for offence of dacoity under s. 395 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, along with others, were placed on their trial before the Assistant Sessions Judge of Chapra in the district of Saran, for the offence of dacoity under s. 395,

facts.text: Appellants along with two others convicted under s. 395 IPC and sentenced to 5 years rigorous imprisonment by Assistant Sessions Judge on December 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: They, along with two others, were convicted under s. 395, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for 5 years, by the Assistant Sessions Judge, by his Judgment

facts.text: Other accused were acquitted by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The other accused were acquitted.

facts.text: Convicted persons appealed to Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The convicted persons preferred an appeal to the High Court at Patna.

facts.text: Patna High Court while admitting appeal called upon appellants to show cause why sentence should not be enhanced.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in its revisional jurisdiction, while admitting the appeal, called upon the appellants to show cause why, in the event of their convictions being maintained,

facts.text: Patna High Court by judgment dated August 4, 1955 allowed appeal of two appellants and acquitted them, maintained conviction of remaining six appellants, enhanced sentence to 10 years RI.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment and order dated August 4, 1955, allowed the appeal of two of the appellants and acquitted them but maintained the conviction as against the

facts.text: Dacoity occurred on the night between July 1 and 2, 1952 in the house of Ranjit Bahadur, a minor.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence of dacoity which is the subjectmatter of the charge against the appellants, along with others, took place on the night between July 1 and 2, 1952, in the

facts.text: 16 or 17 dacoits fully armed with deadly weapons broke open main entrance door with axe after midnight.

anchor.surface_text: house of Ranjit Bahadur, a minor. After midnight, 16 or 17 dacoits, fully armed with various deadly weapons, broke open the main entrance door of the house with an axe.

facts.text: Dacoits broke open boxes, tampered with iron safe, removed articles worth twenty thousand rupees.

anchor.surface_text: After going into the house, they broke open boxes and tampered with the iron safe, and removed articles worth twenty thousand rupees.

facts.text: Inmates of the house were over-powered.

anchor.surface_text: The inmates of the house were over-powered.

facts.text: Some inmates raised alarm by big fire, villagers turned up but did not confront dacoits for fear of being shot, used brickbats.

anchor.surface_text: Some of them, slipping out of the house, raised a big fire which is the customary form of alarm raised against the invading crowd of dacoits. On that alarm, a number

facts.text: Dacoits made good their escape with booty.

anchor.surface_text: of people of the village turned up but had not the courage to face the dacoits for fear of being shot. They contented themselves with using brickbats against the dacoits

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge could not impose sentence exceeding 7 years.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge could not have imposed a term of imprisonment exceeding 7 years.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal limited to question of sentence.

anchor.surface_text: obtained special leave to appeal limited to the question of sentence only, the question being whether the High Court had the jurisdiction to enhance the sentence beyond

facts.text: High Court enhanced sentence from 5 to 10 years rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, enhanced the sentence to 10 years rigorous imprisonment in each and obtained special leave to appeal limited to the question of sentence only, the question

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court had power to enhance sentence beyond trial court's limit up to maximum under IPC.

anchor.surface_text: convicted under s. 395, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for 5 years, by the Assistant Sessions Judge, by his Judgment and order dated December 12, 1953. The other accused were acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 of the Code lays down the sentence which magistrates may, ordinarily, impose, which is a term of imprisonment not exceeding two years, in the case of Presidency Magistrates and Magistrates of the first class omitting all reference to fine.

concepts.interpretation: Ordinary sentencing limit for Presidency Magistrates and first class Magistrates is 2 years imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: But in certain specified areas, s. 30 empowers the Government to invest a District Magistrate or a Magistrate, first class, with the power to try, as a magistrate, all offences not punishable with death.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers certain Magistrates to try serious offences (not punishable with death) and impose up to 7 years.

anchor.surface_text: A magistrate so empowered under s. 30, may pass a sentence of imprisonment for a term of 7 years or less. Thus, the powers of an Assistant Sessions Judge, under s. 31 3 and of a magistrate specially empowered under s. 30 to impose a sentence of imprisonment, are the same, the terms of s. 31 3 and s. 34 being almost identical.

concepts.interpretation: Related to sentencing powers analogous to s.31(3) for empowered Magistrates.

issues.text: whether the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction, has the power to enhance the sentence, as it has done in the instant case, beyond the limit of the maximum sentence that could have been imposed by the trial court, on the accused persons.

issues.text: whether the High Court had the jurisdiction to enhance the sentence beyond the limits of the power of the trial court itself

anchor.surface_text: And lastly, it was contended that in any view of the matter, in the circumstances of this case, the sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment is too severe. In our opinion, there is no substance in any one of these contentions.

arguments.claim: Offence of dacoity increased tremendously; very heinous as attacks innocents sleeping; 5 years extremely inadequate

anchor.surface_text: On the question of sentence, the High Court observed that the offence of dacoity has increased tremendously. It is a very heinous offence as innocent persons, while sleeping in their houses, are attacked and their belongings are taken by force. The High Court, therefore, was of the opinion that a sentence of five years

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nal Procedure, which limits the power of the High Court in the way suggested on behalf of the appellants, and there are numberreasons which militate a

arguments.court_reasoning: Justified in imposing 10 years given circumstances

arguments.claim: s.439(1) CrPC clothes HC with appellate powers including to enhance sentence; no words of limitation so up to IPC maximum

anchor.surface_text: The power of the High Court to enhance a sentence, is contained in sub-s. 1 of s. 439 of the Code, which clothes the High Court with the powers of a Court of Appeal under the Code, as also the power to enhance the sentence. Sub-s. 1 itself, does not contain any words of limitation on the power to enhance the sentence. Hence, the High Court could impose any sentence up to the maximum limit prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, for a particular offence.

arguments.claim: Fact that trial by court with limited sentencing power does not limit HC's power to impose adequate sentence

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the trial of the case was entrusted to a court with a limited jurisdiction in the matter of sentence, could not be used to impose a limit on the power of a High Court to impose a proper and adequate sentence.

arguments.claim: s.439(3) CrPC limits HC enhancement only for sentences by magistrates not empowered under s.30; no limit for Sessions/Assistant Sessions

anchor.surface_text: That the Legislature did not intend to impose a limit on the power of the High Court to inflict an adequate sentence in a trial held by a Court of Session, is made clear by the provisions of sub-s. 3 of s. 439... Sub-section 3 of s. 439, thus, makes it clear that there is no limitation on the power of the High Court to enhance a sentence to the maximum prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, except in cases tried by magistrates other than those especially empowered under s. 30, Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Powers of Assistant Sessions Judge under s.31(3) same as magistrate under s.30/34; s.439(3) exception covers both but HC not limited thereby

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 of the Code lays down... Thus, the powers of an Assistant Sessions Judge, under s. 31 3 and of a magistrate specially empowered under s. 30 to impose a sentence of imprisonment, are the same, the terms of s. 31 3 and s. 34 being almost identical. From the terms of s. 439 3 , it is clear that the only limitation...

arguments.claim: No provision in CrPC limits HC power as suggested; no decisions support appellant's contention

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants very properly informed us that there are some reported decisions of some of the High Courts which have gone against his contention, and that there is no decision which has taken a view in support of his contention. In our opinion, there is no provision in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits the power of the High Court in the way suggested on behalf of the appellants,

arguments.claim: Bed Raj case requires sentence enhancement as judicial discretion, not lightly; only if inadequate on full consideration

anchor.surface_text: The case relied upon... Bed Raj v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 , also seems to point to the same conclusion as will appear from the following observations at p. 584 Now, though no limitation has been placed on the High Courts power to enhance it is nevertheless a judicial act and, like all judicial acts involving an exercise of discretion, must be exercised along wellknown judicial lines.

arguments.claim: HC properly exercised discretion: dacoity incidence high, serious case warrants deterrent 10 years

anchor.surface_text: On the second contention, there is no doubt that the question of sentence is a matter of discretion which has to be exercised in a judicial way... In the instant case, the High Court has pointed out that the incidence of the offence of dacoity has gone up to such an extent that in proved cases of serious dacoity, like the one in hand, deterrent punishment is called for.

arguments.claim: Enhanced sentence not excessive given circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, justified in imposing the sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment. In view of the circumstances disclosed in the case, as indicated above, it cannot be asserted that the sentence as enhanced by the High Court is excessive.

holdings.text: The High Court in its revisional jurisdiction has the power to enhance the sentence beyond the limit of the maximum sentence that could have been imposed by the trial court, up to the maximum prescribed by the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The power of the High Court to enhance a sentence, is contained in sub-s. 1 of s. 439 of the Code, which clothes the High Court with the powers of a Court of Appeal under the Code, as also the power to enhance the sentence. Sub-s. 1 itself, does not contain any words of limitation on the power to enhance the sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.439(1) CrPC grants appellate powers including enhancement without express limitation; trial court's limited sentencing power does not restrict HC.

holdings.text: Sub-section 3 of s. 439 CrPC imposes no limitation on the High Court's power to enhance sentence to IPC maximum in trials by Assistant Sessions Judge, as the limitation applies only to magistrates not empowered under s.30 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 3 of s. 439, thus, makes it clear that there is no limitation on the power of the High Court to enhance a sentence to the maximum prescribed by the Indian Penal Code, except in cases tried by magistrates other than those especially empowered under s. 30, Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.439(3) explicitly limits only unempowered magistrates; Assistant Sessions Judge powers analogous to empowered magistrates under s.30/34 but exception does not bind HC in Sessions trials.

holdings.text: There is no provision in the Code of Criminal Procedure which limits the power of the High Court to enhance sentence beyond trial court's limit as contended.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no provision in the Code of Criminal Procedure, which limits the power of the High Court in the way suggested on behalf of the appellants, and there are no reasons which militate against the decision of the High Courts taking that view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory text or precedent supports limitation; some HCs held opposite.

holdings.text: The High Court properly exercised judicial discretion in enhancing the sentence, having considered the rising incidence of dacoity and seriousness of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: Now, though no limitation has been placed on the High Courts power to enhance it is nevertheless a judicial act and, like all judicial acts involving an exercise of discretion, must be exercised along wellknown judicial lines.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Bed Raj v. State of UP, enhancement requires full consideration of circumstances; HC did so noting dacoity's heinous nature and prevalence.

holdings.text: The sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment is not excessive given the circumstances of the serious dacoity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, justified in imposing the sentence of 10 years rigorous imprisonment. In view of the circumstances disclosed in the case, as indicated above, it cannot be asserted that the sentence as enhanced by the High Court is excessive.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dacoity involved armed invasion, overpowering inmates, loot of Rs.20,000; rising incidence warrants deterrent punishment; 5 years inadequate.
